unnormalised: **New Traffic Regulations Aim to Enhance Road Safety in India**
normalised: New Traffic Regulations Aim to Enhance Road Safety in India

unnormalised: New Delhi: The Ministry of Road Transport and Highways, inspired by the principles outlined in the popular Bollywood film 'Traffic', has announced updated traffic regulations aimed at improving road safety across India. These changes, effective from October 27th, 2024, include stricter enforcement of speed limits, particularly in urban areas.
normalised: New Delhi: The Ministry of Road Transport and Highways, inspired by the principles outlined in the popular Bollywood film 'Traffic', has announced updated traffic regulations aimed at improving road safety across India. These changes, effective from october twenty seventh, two thousand and twenty four, include stricter enforcement of speed limits, particularly in urban areas.

unnormalised: Speeding fines have been increased, with first-time offenders now facing a penalty of Rs. 2000. The regulations also mandate the use of rear seatbelts, a measure previously often overlooked, with a fine of Rs. 1000 for non-compliance.
normalised: Speeding fines have been increased, with first-time offenders now facing a penalty of rupee two thousand. The regulations also mandate the use of rear seatbelts, a measure previously often overlooked, with a fine of rupee one thousand for non-compliance.

unnormalised: The Indian Institute of Technology (IIT) Delhi collaborated in analyzing accident data to identify high-risk zones. Based on their findings, speed limits on certain stretches of the Delhi-Jaipur highway have been reduced to 80 km/h for cars and 60 km/h for heavy vehicles.
normalised: The Indian Institute of Technology (I I T) Delhi collaborated in analyzing accident data to identify high-risk zones. Based on their findings, speed limits on certain stretches of the Delhi-Jaipur highway have been reduced to eighty kilometer per hour for cars and sixty kilometer per hour for heavy vehicles.

unnormalised: Authorities will be using advanced technology, including AI-powered cameras, to monitor traffic violations and issue e-challans. These new regulations are expected to significantly reduce road accidents and fatalities, making Indian roads safer for all.
